div1.p: Love is grateful that the military did not reject him because of his defective vision. [Courtesy of The Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia Library]

div1.head: Letter from Albert G. Love to Jefferson Randolph Kean, August 12, 1943
div1.opener:
IN REPLY REFER TO SPMCG
AGL:jm
WAR DEPARTMENT
SERVICES OF SUPPLY
OFFICE OF THE SURGEON GENERAL
WASHINGTON
12 August 1943
Brig. Gen. J. R. Kean,
2804 N Street, N. W.,
Washington 7, D.C.
My dear General:
div1.p:
Your letter of August 10 reached me yesterday afternoon.
I was very much interested in the contents of the letter. Your
comments about Hanberry were quite interesting. I will be glad
at some time, if you wish, to go to the Census to look up the
case of Forbes. I presume, however, that the Veterans Administra-
tion have done all that they could to locate him.

Yes, monocular vision is considered a major defect. For-
tunately for the good of the Medical Department they were not quite
so careful in evaluating defects when you came into the service. I
remember that even when I took the examination there were no definite
instructions with regard to the acuity of vision required. As I
recall, the regulations simply stated that the defective vision must
not be excessive. Phalen, who examined me, was very much in a
quandary whether to reject or pass me since I had some defect.
Fortunately for me, I was able to persuade him that my defect was not
excessive.
div1.closer:
Very best regards.
Cordially, Albert G. Love ALBERT G. LOVE,
Colonel, Medical Corps.
FOR VICTORY
BUY
UNITED
STATES
WAR
BONDS
AND
STAMPS
ALL COMMUNICATIONS SHOULD BE ADDRESSED TO “THE SURGEON GENERAL, U. S. ARMY, WASHINGTON, D. C.”
